Based on the search results, I can provide information about scholarly interpretations of Robinson Crusoe relating to themes of Eden, purgatory, blank slate, and tabula rasa:

## Edenic Interpretations

Robinson's island is described as "a pristine land of surpassing beauty" that "seems nothing short of Eden" with the country appearing "so fresh, so green, so flourishing, every thing being in a constant Verdure, or Flourish of Spring, that it looked like a planted Garden." This Edenic imagery positions the island as a paradisiacal space where Robinson can experience a form of spiritual renewal.

## Purgatorial Elements

The setting of the island serves as "a catalyst for his redemption and spiritual revival, echoing themes of repentance found in Puritan literature" and "allows him to rise above his middle-class origins and reunite with his faith." This suggests the island functions as a purgatorial space where Robinson undergoes spiritual purification.

## Blank Slate/Tabula Rasa Themes

The crucial aspect of the novel is "Defoe's account of how a civilization is born" where "what transforms chaos into cosmos, survivalism into society, is obedience to God." The island setting allows Robinson to essentially start from scratch, building not just physical structures but also rebuilding his spiritual and moral character.

During his island stay, "Crusoe works diligently, building not only a serviceable home, but also almost every convenience to which he was accustomed in England" and "ironically ends up following the very Puritan dictates that he originally left England to escape," developing "a sense of wholehearted inventiveness" and returning "to the Protestant religion he spurned."

## Spiritual Transformation

On the island, "He reads the Bible and becomes religious, thanking God for his fate in which nothing is missing but human society." This represents Robinson's transformation from his original rebellious state to spiritual acceptance and gratitude.

The scholarly interpretation suggests that Defoe uses the island setting as both an Edenic paradise and a purgatorial space where Robinson can undergo complete spiritual and moral reconstruction - effectively becoming a blank slate upon which divine providence can write a new character.
